cur.html:
1. Variable swapping by destructuring assignment

You can use ES6 destructuring assignment syntax to swap two variables

let a = 5,
  b = ((10)[(a, b)] = [b, a]);

console.log(a, b); // 10 5

2. Avoiding for loops by creating array

You could write a simple for loop to iterate over some range like below:

let sum = 0;

for (let i = 5; i < 10; i += 1) {
  sum += i;
}

However, if you want to write a range loop in functional programming way, you can create an array like below:

const sum = Array.from(new Array(5), (_, k) => k + 5).reduce((acc, cur) => acc + cur, 0);

3. Removing repeated values in an array using

You can use Set in javascript for removing repeated value in an array. Set

â€œThe Set object lets you store unique values of any type, A value in the Set may only occur onceâ€ - MDN

const names = ['Lee', 'Kim', 'Park', 'Lee', 'Kim'];

const uniqueNamesWithArrayFrom = Array.from(new Set(names));

or;

const uniqueNamesWithSpread = [...new Set(names)];

4. Merge two objects by using spread syntax

You can merge two objects and assign to new variable with spread syntax like below:

const person = {
  name: 'Lee Sun-Hyoup',
  familyName: 'Lee',
  givenName: 'Sun-Hyoup',
};

const company = {
  name: 'Cobalt. Inc.',
  address: 'Seoul',
};

const leeSunHyoup = { ...person, ...company };

console.log(leeSunHyoup);

// {
//   address: â€œSeoulâ€
//     familyName: â€œLeeâ€
//   givenName: â€œSun-Hyoupâ€
//   name: "Cobalt. Inc." // note that if there is a same key value, last one will take over
// }

5. && and ||

// when you want to give a default value to a variable:
const name = participantName || 'Guest';

// when you want to conditionally operate some function:
// func will only be execute if flag is true
flag && func();

// or during object merging

const makeCompany = (showAddress) => {
  return {
    name: 'Cobalt. Inc.',
    ...(showAddress && { address: 'Seoul' }),
  };
};

console.log(makeCompany(false));
// { name: 'Cobalt. Inc.' }
console.log(makeCompany(true));
// { name: 'Cobalt. Inc.', address: 'Seoul' }

6. object destructuring

Letâ€™s get values that are actually being used:

const person = {
    name: 'Lee Sun-Hyoup',
    familyName: 'Lee',
    givenName: 'Sun-Hyoup'
    company: 'Cobalt. Inc.',
    address: 'Seoul',
}

const { familyName, givenName } = person;

7.

Use variable name as key in an javascript object

const name = 'Lee Sun-Hyoup';
const company = 'Cobalt';
const person = {
  name,
  company,
};
console.log(person);
// {
//   name: 'Lee Sun-Hyoup'
//   company: 'Cobalt',
// }

8. Destructuring object for function argument

destructure an object that is passed to a function as an argument:

const makeCompany = ({ name, address, serviceName }) => {
  return {
    name,
    address,
    serviceName,
  };
};
const cobalt = makeCompany({ name: 'Cobalt. Inc.', address: 'Seoul', serviceName: 'Present' });

9. Letâ€™s make object key dynamic!

From ES6, you can make your object key dynamic like BTSğŸ˜…

const nameKey = 'name';
const emailKey = 'email';
const person = {
  [nameKey]: 'Lee Sun-Hyoup',
  [emailKey]: 'kciter@naver.com',
};
console.log(person);
// {
//   name: 'Lee Sun-Hyoup',
//   email: 'kciter@naver.com'
// }

10. !! operator to change null, or undefined to boolean value

function check(variable) {
  if (!!variable) {
    console.log(variable);
  } else {
    console.log('wrong value');
  }
}
check(null); // wrong value
check(3.14); // 3.14
check(undefined); // wrong value
check(0); // wrong value
check('Good'); // Good
check(''); // wrong value
check(NaN); // wrong value
check(5); // 5
  • 1. Variable swapping by destructuring assignment
  • 2. Avoiding for loops by creating array
  • 3. Removing repeated values in an array using
  • 4. Merge two objects by using spread syntax
  • 5. && and ||
  • 6. object destructuring
  • 7.
  • 8. Destructuring object for function argument
  • 9. Letâ€™s make object key dynamic!
  • 10. !! operator to change null, or undefined to boolean value

class Dict:
    def __init__(self) -> None:
        self.items = [None] * 8

    def put(self, key, value) -> None:
        self.items[hash(key)% len(self.items)]  = value

    def get(self, key):
        index = hash(key)%len(self.items)

        return self.items[index]

Chaining

chaining ë°©ë²• ì‚´í´ë³´ë©´ ë°°ì—´ì— ë“¤ì–´ê°ˆ ìˆ˜ ìˆëŠ” ì—”íŠ¸ë¦¬ì˜ ìˆ˜ì— ì œí•œì„ ë‘ì§€ ì•ŠìŒìœ¼ë¡œì„œ, ëª¨ë“  ìë£Œë¥¼ í•´ì‹œí…Œì´ë¸”ì— ë‹´ëŠ” ê²ƒì´ë‹¤. í•´ë‹¹ ë²„í‚·ì— ì´ë¯¸ ë°ì´í„°ê°€ ìˆë‹¤ë©´ ì—°ê²° ë¦¬ìŠ¤íŠ¸ (linked list) ë°©ì‹ì„ ì‚¬ìš©í•˜ì—¬ ë…¸ë“œì™€ ë…¸ë“œë¥¼ ì²´ì¸ì²˜ëŸ¼ ì—°ê²°í•˜ëŠ” ë°©ë²•ì´ë‹¤.

ì´ ë°©ë²•ì˜ ì¥ì ì€ ìœ ì—°í•˜ë©°, ì‚­ì œ ë° ì‚½ì…ì˜ ì‹œê°„ë³µì¡ë„ê°€ O(1)ìœ¼ë¡œ ë¹ ë¥´ë‹¤ëŠ” ì ì´ ìˆë‹¤.

ì •ë¦¬

í•´ì‰¬ í•¨ìˆ˜(Hash Function)ëŠ” ì„ì˜ì˜ ê¸¸ì´ë¥¼ ê°–ëŠ” ë©”ì‹œì§€ë¥¼ ì…ë ¥í•˜ì—¬ ê³ ì •ëœ ê¸¸ì´ì˜ í•´ì‰¬ê°’ì„ ì¶œë ¥í•˜ëŠ” í•¨ìˆ˜ì´ë‹¤.

í•´ì‰¬ í…Œì´ë¸”ì˜ ë‚´ë¶€ êµ¬í˜„ì€ í‚¤ë¥¼ í•´ì‰¬ í•¨ìˆ˜ë¥¼ í†µí•´ ì„ì˜ì˜ ê°’ìœ¼ë¡œ ë³€ê²½í•œ ë’¤ ë°°ì—´ì˜ ì¸ë±ìŠ¤ë¡œ ë³€í™˜í•˜ì—¬ í•´ë‹¹í•˜ëŠ” ê°’ì— ë°ì´í„°ë¥¼ ì €ì¥í•œë‹¤.

ë§Œì•½, í•´ì‰¬ ê°’ í˜¹ì€ ì¸ë±ìŠ¤ê°€ ì¤‘ë³µë˜ì–´ ì¶©ëŒì´ ì¼ì–´ë‚œë‹¤ë©´?

prev.html:
ğŸ¤” Missing â€œkeyâ€ prop..? but no array..?

If you are reading this post, youâ€™ve probably got an error like this where you donâ€™t even have any array.map in your component.

This is an issue with eslint-plugin-react version 7.29.0.

To fix the issue, simply down grade eslint-plugin-react to 7.28.0.

npm i eslint-plugin-react@7.28.0

Reference: https://github.com/yannickcr/eslint-plugin-react/issues/3215

frontmatter.title: Missing "key" prop for element when there is no array
